definitions.definition: the ability to say or write things that are both clever and humorous

examples.text: to have a **quick/sharp/dry/ready wit**
a woman of wit and intelligence
a book full of the **wit and wisdom** of his 30 years in politics
He had a dry wit.
He has plenty of wit and imagination.
He was blessed with great charm and a quick wit.
I wanted to bowl him over with my sparkling wit.
She had to use all her native wit (= the wit she was born with) to convince the police.

definitions.definition: a person who has the ability to say or write things that are both clever and humorous

examples.text: a well-known wit and raconteur

definitions.definition: your ability to think quickly and clearly and to make good decisions

examples.text: He needed all his wits to find his way out.
The game was a long **battle of wits**.
Kate paused and **gathered her wits**.
a chance to **pit your wits against** *(= compete with, using your intelligence)* our quiz champion
She couldn't seem to gather her wits and tell us what had happened.
The game allows you to match wits with a computer criminal.
The strike developed into a battle of wits between management and workers.
Living alone in the country had dulled his wits.

definitions.definition: having the type of intelligence mentioned

examples.text: a quick-witted group of students

definitions.definition: the intelligence or good sense to know what is the right thing to do

examples.text: At least you had the wit to ask for help.
It should not be **beyond the wit of man** to resolve this dispute.
I hope he has the wit to take the key with him.
I hope you had the wits to apologize.
You'd think they'd have the wit to ask for help.
It shouldn't be beyond the wit of man to solve this issue.

definitions.definition: to be so worried by a problem that you do not know what to do next

examples.text: She was at her wits’ end wondering how she’d manage it all in the time.
I'm at my wits' end trying to cope with his moods.

definitions.definition: to be very frightened; to frighten somebody very much

examples.text: I was scared out of my wits!
The latest news has scared the wits out of investors.

definitions.definition: to be aware of what is happening around you and ready to think and act quickly

examples.text: They do tough interviews so you'll need to have your wits about you.

definitions.definition: to earn money by clever or sometimes dishonest means
you use to wit when you are about to be more exact about something that you have just referred to

examples.text: Pilot error, to wit failure to follow procedures, was the cause of the accident.

wordOrigin: Old English wit(t), gewit(t), denoting the mind as the seat of consciousness, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch weet and German Witz, also to wit in the archaic sense ‘have knowledge’.
